Award.AwardTitle: Travel Grant to Attend Big Data in Software Engineering Track

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports participants to attend the Big Data in Software Engineering track of the Midwest Big Data Summer School. The Midwest Big Data Summer School series is a 5-day training activity for Early Career Researchers. The 2017 edition of the event will be held on July 10-14, 2017 in Ames, Iowa. This summer school is a one-week, intensive curriculum aimed at early career researchers to get them started in data-driven research. The school includes full-day lectures on topics ranging from data acquisition, data preprocessing, exploratory data analysis, descriptive data analysis, data analysis tools and techniques, visualization and communication, ethical issues in data science, reproducibility and repeatability, and understanding of domain/context.

In the field of Software Engineering, big data analytics for empirical research has expanded as a research area. The Big Data in Software Engineering track at the Summer School will train researchers on the skills, tools and techniques to perform this research. Overall, it is a community building activity that may stimulate research collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the Big Data in Software Engineering track at the 2018 Midwest Big Data Summer School that was later renamed to Software Analytics track to be more consistent with the terminology used in the software engineering community. 

The 2018 Midwest Big Data Summer School for Early Career Researchers was held from May 14-17, 2018 in Ames, Iowa. This summer school is designed as an intensive curriculum aimed at early career researchers to get them started in data-driven research. The school included full-day lectures on topics ranging from: data acquisition, data preprocessing, exploratory data analysis, descriptive data analysis, data analysis tools and techniques, visualization and communication, ethical issues in data science, reproducibility and repeatability, and understanding of domain/context.

The last day of the summer school consists of tracks where each individual track focuses on a subarea of Big Data analysis. This year's tracks included Foundations of Data Science, Software Analytics, Digital Agriculture, and Big Data Applications. Each track consists of tutorials and invited lectures that highlighted current research methodologies and challenges. Participants could choose a track that they wish to attend when they register.

This grant supported the software analytics track that was very well attended. In total, there were twenty-six different attendees that stayed throughout the day.  

The overall summer school was chaired by the PI, and the software analytics track was chaired by Dr. Wei Le from Iowa State University and Dr. ThanVu Nguyen from the University of Nebraska Lincoln. 

The software analytics track was a full-day event that was organized as follows. Audris Mockus from the University of Tennesse presented the opening talk on Foundations and Tutorials of Big Data Science on Software Analytics. Jacek Czerwonka from Microsoft presented a talk on how data helps Microsoft configure and run large-scale software projects. Will Snipes from ABB presented an overview of the team analytics portal project. Ganesha Upadhyaya from Huawei presented an overview of collective program analysis.

Overall, the software analytics track, organized for the first time, turned out to be very successful and saw consistent engagement throughout the day. All of the external speakers urged the organizers to run this track again next year.
